nodes.title: Understanding Series RLC Circuit Basics
nodes.concept_summary: In a series RLC circuit, all components (resistor, inductor, and capacitor) are connected end-to-end. The same current flows through each component.
nodes.analogy: Imagine water flowing through a pipe with a valve, a coil, and a balloon. The flow rate is the same everywhere in the pipe.

interactive_element.prompt: If you increase the resistance (R), what happens to the current (I) in the circuit?

nodes.title: Voltage Across Components in Series RLC Circuit
nodes.concept_summary: The voltage across each component is determined by its impedance, which depends on the frequency (ω) of the AC supply.
nodes.analogy: Think of a road where traffic lights control the flow. Each light (component) has its own schedule and affects the overall traffic pattern (voltage).

interactive_element.prompt: The voltage across the resistor is given by ___. The voltage across the inductor is given by ___.
interactive_element.expected_answer: V_R = I R, V_L = ω L I
interactive_element.clarification: Impedance and phase shift play roles

nodes.title: Power Factor in Series RLC Circuit
nodes.concept_summary: The power factor is the cosine of the phase angle between the voltage and current. It indicates how much of the circuit's power is actually doing useful work.
nodes.analogy: Think of a phone charging cable. If it’s not fully charged, some energy is lost as heat (lower power factor).

interactive_element.prompt: Compare the power factor when the circuit has only R to when it includes L and C.
interactive_element.expected_answer: Purely resistive: 1; With inductor and capacitor: less than 1
interactive_element.clarification: In phase for resistor, lagging for inductor, leading for capacitor

checkpoint.question: What is the primary effect of adding an inductor (L) and a capacitor (C) to a series circuit with just a resistor (R)?
options: Changes the phase relationship between voltage and current
checkpoint.explanation: Adding L and C changes how the circuit behaves at different frequencies, affecting the phase angle.
